newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: S.Korea March trade deficit widens to $1.88 bln.
newsitem.headline: S.Korea March trade deficit widens to $1.88 bln.

text.p: South Korea's customs-cleared trade deficit widened to $1.88 billion in March from a $446 million deficit a year earlier, provisional figures released by the trade ministry showed on Tuesday.
NOTE: in millions of dollars, February figures revised
South Korea's customs-cleared trade deficit totalled $7.43 billion in the first three months of this year, up from $4.17 billion in the same 1996 period, the ministry figures showed.
February exports fell 2.9 percent year-on-year, compared with a 16.9 percent increase a year earlier.
Imports in the month rose 9.0 percent year-on-year, against a 4.0 percent growth in February 1996.
A trade ministry statement attributed the huge shortfall to increased imports of oil and slowing overseas shipments of key export items.
Exports of semiconductors fell by 42.8 percent in March, compared with a 42.4 percent rise a year earlier.

But the statement said semiconductor exports showed signs of improving, aided by a production cut in 16-megabit DRAMs that was pushing up prices. It said the export price of 16-megabit DRAMs rose to $9 in February from $8 in January.
Exports, excluding semiconductors, rose 5.4 percent in March on steady sales of steel and petroleum products. This compares with a 4.7 percent rise in February.
March oil imports rose to $1.69 billion from $690 million a year earlier.
The statement said domestic refiners imported more crude after expanding refining facilities.
But imports of raw materials and capital goods, including machinery, continued to fall as facility investment by South Korean companies slowed.
The March deficit compared with a shortfall of $2.09 billion in February and $3.47 billion in January. The statement said the deficit should continue to narrow month-on-month.
The trade ministry earlier forecast a $14 billion trade deficit this year against a $20.62 billion shortfall in 1996.
